choices.text: HNPCC
Gorlin syndrome
Von Hipplel - Lindau syndrome
Peutz Jeghers syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with anemia and abdominal pain. On examination, he has pigmented macules over the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Further investigations reveal loss-of-function mutations of the STK11 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jeghers syndrome

Option D:

  • The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz Jeghers syndrome. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder due to loss of function mutations of STK11.
  • It is associated with arborizing polyps of the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine > colon > stomach).
  • It increases the risk of multiple epithelial cancers, particularly of colon, breast, lung, pancreas, and thyroid.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 gene, which increase the risk of several epithelial cancers.

Explanation:

Option A. HNPCC: HNPCC, also known as Lynch syndrome, is an autosomal dominant condition predisposing individuals to early-onset colorectal cancer and other malignancies. It is associated with mutations in mismatch repair genes, not STK11.

Option B. Gorlin syndrome: Gorlin syndrome, or nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, is characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas, odontogenic keratocysts, and skeletal anomalies. It is associated with mutations in the PTCH1 gene, not STK11.

Option C. Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary cancer syndrome associated with a variety of tumors, including hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is related to mutations in the VHL gene.

Educational Objective:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation, due to mutations in the STK11 gene, and it elevates the risk of multiple cancers.

choices.text: WT-1
APC
MSH2
p53

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her mother died of endometrial cancer when she was 50, and her 42-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with colon cancer. You begin to suspect a familial cancer syndrome. Which gene in this family is most likely to be mutated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MSH2

Option C:

This family likely has Hereditary Non Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome. Often, gynecologic malignancies (usually endometrial, ovarian tumors) are diagnosed before colorectal tumors in female patients with HNPCC.

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 representing the primary culprits.

Explanation:

Option A. WT-1 mutations predispose patients to Wilms tumors.

Option B. APC is mutated in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Option D. Germline mutations in p53 are seen in Li Fraumeni syndrome.

Educational Objective:

This family likely has Lynch syndrome (Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer, HNPCC), associated with mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes such as MSH2, often presenting with gynecological malignancies before colorectal tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page:314

choices.text: It regulates cellular senescence
P53 inactivation causes cell cycle arrest at G2-M
Cancers demonstrate biallelic loss of function mutations in TP53
p53 can be inactivated by E6 protein of HPV

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a strong family history of various cancers is being evaluated for genetic predisposition. Understanding the role of tumor suppressor genes, particularly p53, is crucial for her assessment. Which of the following statements about the function of p53 is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P53 inactivation causes cell cycle arrest at G2-M

Option B:

P53 is the tumor suppressor gene and activation (not inactivation) causes cell cycle arrest at the G1-S and G2-M phase of the cell cycle. P53 regulates:

  • Cell cycle progression
  • DNA repair
  • Cellular senescence
  • Apoptosis

 

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to a defect in the tumor suppressor gene P53 located on chromosome 17.

p53 inactivation causes cell cycle arrest at the G2-M checkpoint. This statement is false. The activation of p53, not inactivation, leads to cell cycle arrest at the G1-S and G2-M checkpoints as a response to DNA damage.

Explanation:

Option A. It regulates cellular senescence. This is true. p53 plays a role in halting cell proliferation when cells become old (senescent), potentially preventing the replication of damaged DNA.

Option C. Cancers often exhibit biallelic loss of function mutations in TP53. True. Many cancers demonstrate loss of function in both alleles of the TP53 gene, which encodes the p53 protein, leading to unregulated cell growth.

Option D. p53 can be inactivated by the E6 protein of HPV. This is true. Human papillomavirus (HPV) can lead to cancer development through its E6 protein, which inactivates p53, thereby preventing it from performing its tumor suppressor functions.

Educational Objective:

p53 inactivation does not cause cell cycle arrest at the G2-M checkpoint. Activation of p53 leads to cell cycle arrest, allowing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable. This function is critical in preventing the proliferation of cells with genetic damage.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page:296

choices.text: Ash leaf macule
Shagreen patch
Schwannoma
Adenoma sebaceum

questions.text: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

Option C:

 

  • Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by the development of hamartomas and benign neoplasms involving the brain and other tissues.  Elsewhere in the body, renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis and cardiac rhabdomyomas develop over childhood and adolescence. Cysts may be found at various sites, including the liver, kidneys, and pancreas.
  • Cutaneous lesions include angiofibromas, localized leathery thickenings (shagreen patches), hypopigmented areas (ash-leaf patches), sebaceous adenomas and subungual fibromas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ash leaf macules are hypopigmented lesions typically found in tuberous sclerosis. They are one of the earliest dermatological signs of the disease and can be observed with a Wood's lamp examination.

 

Option B: Shagreen patches are areas of thick, leathery skin found typically on the lower back; they are connective tissue nevi associated with tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option D: Adenoma sebaceum, which is a misnomer for facial angiofibromas, manifests as small red or pink papules, commonly found on the face, particularly the nose and cheeks, in tuberous sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is not associated with tuberous sclerosis; rather, it is commonly associated with neurofibromatosis, another phakomatosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1302

choices.text: Chromosome 13
Chromosome 11
Chromosome 17
Chromosome 22

questions.text: BRCA 1 gene is located on:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromosome 17

 

Explanation:

 

  • Tumor-suppressor gene, BRCA-1 (17q21) encodes a zinc finger protein, and the product therefore may function as a transcription factor. The gene appears to be involved in gene repair.
  • BRCA-2 (13q12) is also associated with an increased incidence of breast cancer in men and women.

 

Educational objective:

 

BRCA 1 gene is located on Chromosome 17q and BRCA2 gene is located on chromosome 13q.

 

Ref: Robbin 10th/ 1045

choices.text: p53
BRCA-1
Retinoblastoma (Rb)
H-Ras

questions.text: Increased susceptibility to sporadic breast cancer is likely to be associated with a mutation in the following gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) p53

 

Option A:

 

Breast cancer can be either familial (associated with germline mutation) or sporadic (associated with somatic mutation).

 

The p53 gene, known for its role in cell cycle control and apoptosis, is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This hereditary condition predisposes individuals to a variety of cancers, including breast cancer, at an early age. Sporadic breast cancer is associated with mutation in p53 gene (p53 defect is present in 40% of human breast cancer as an acquired defect) and PTEN gene.

 

Since, incidence of sporadic cancer is much more than familial cancer, so the most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility to breast cancer should be answered as p53.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The BRCA1 gene mutation carries a high risk for developing breast and ovarian cancers. Individuals with this mutation have a lifetime risk of breast cancer that is significantly higher than the general population.

 

Option C. While the Rb gene is crucial in controlling cell proliferation and its mutation is primarily associated with retinoblastoma, it is not a leading cause of breast cancer.

 

Option D. H-Ras is part of the Ras gene family; while mutations in these genes can lead to cancer, they are not typically associated with hereditary breast cancer syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p53 gene mutation is the most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility to breast cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1051

choices.text: p53
BRCA-2
Her 2/Neu gene
C-myc gene

questions.text: A female patient presented with a firm mass of 2 × 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. She gives a family history of ovarian carcinoma. The investigation that needs to be done to assess for mutations is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA2

 

Option B:

 

BRCA2 is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene are known to significantly increase the risk of both breast and ovarian cancers in bwith a history suggestive of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The p53 gene, when mutated, can lead to a variety of cancers; however, in the context of a family history suggesting a hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome, BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene testing is more directly relevant.

 

Option C. Her 2/Neu gene amplification is associated with breast cancer aggressiveness and treatment decisions but is not a part of routine genetic screening for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

 

Option D. C-myc is an oncogene implicated in the pathogenesis of various cancers, including breast cancer, but it does not have a direct role in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA2 genetic testing is indicated in a patient with a breast mass and a family history of ovarian carcinoma, as mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are strongly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1058
